sections.title: Entering Amounts
content: The calculator accepts multiple formats: whole numbers (2), decimals (1.5), simple fractions (1/2), and mixed numbers (1 1/2). Common fractions like 1/4, 1/3, 1/2, 2/3, and 3/4 are preserved in the output when possible for easier measuring.

Always check for doneness using temperature or visual cues rather than relying solely on time

sections.title: Common Questions
content:
Q: Do cook times change when scaling?
Often yes. Double batches may need wider pans or slightly longer cooking but rarely double the time. Always check doneness by temperature and texture rather than clock time alone.

Q: How do I handle spices?
For strong spices or salt, scale slightly less than linear for huge batches, then adjust to taste at the end.

Q: What about baking?
Baked goods are sensitive. Scale carefully, keep ratios intact, and bake in multiple pans rather than one massive pan when possible.

Q: Can I switch units?
Record ingredients in the units you measure with. If you need conversions, pair this with a unit converter or standard kitchen conversion chart.

Q: How do fractions display?
The tool preserves common kitchen fractions for readability, so you'll see friendly measurements like 1/4 cup instead of 0.25 cup when possible.
